question: What is the peak efficiency of the CPS 100/125kW string inverters?
answer: The peak efficiency is 99.1%.
context:
Technical Data
Datasheet
100/125kW, 1500Vdc String Inverters for North America
CPS SCH100/125KTL-DO/US-600
The 100 & 125kW high power CPS three phase string inverters are designed for ground mount applications. The units are high
performance, advanced and reliable inverters designed specifically for the North American environment and grid. High efficiency
at 99.1% peak and 98.5% CEC, wide operating voltages, broad temperature ranges and a NEMA Type 4X enclosure enable this
inverter platform to operate at high performance across many applications. The CPS 100/125kW products ship with the Standard
or Centralized Wire-box, each fully integrated and separable with AC and DC disconnect switches. The Standard Wire-box inlcudes
touch safe fusing for up to 20 strings. The CPS Flex Gateway enables communication, controls and remote product upgrades.
Key Features
NFPA 70, NEC 2014 and 2017 compliant NEMA Type 4X outdoor rated, tough tested enclosure
Touch safe DC Fuse holders adds convenience and safety Advanced Smart-Grid features (CA Rule 21 certified)
CPS Flex Gateway enables remote FW upgrades kVA Headroom yields 100kW @ 0.9PF and 125kW @ 0.95PF
Integrated AC & DC disconnect switches Generous 1.87 and 1.5 DC/AC Inverter Load Ratios
1 MPPT with 20 fused inputs for maximum flexibility Separable wire-box design for fast service
Copper and Aluminum compatible AC connections Standard 5 year warranty with extensions to 20 years
100/125KTL Standard Wire-box 100/125KTL Centralized Wire-box

question: What National Electrical Code (NEC) versions are the CPS 100/125kW string inverters compliant with?
answer: The CPS 100/125kW string inverters are compliant with NFPA 70, NEC 2014 and 2017.

question: According to Article 600, what information must be included on the label of a sign that has had its illumination system retrofitted?
answer: The sign must be marked that the illumination system has been replaced, include the kit providers and installer's name, logo, or unique identifier, and if equipped with tubular light-emitting diode lamps powered by existing sign sockets, include a label alerting service personnel that the sign has been modified, including a warning not to install fluorescent lamps.

CHAPTER 6

 Chapter 6 Special Equipment
 ARTICLE 600
 Electric Signs and Outline Lighting
 Part I. General
 600.1 Scope. This article covers the installation of conductors,
equipment, and field wiring for electric signs, retrofit kits, and
outline lighting, regardless of voltage. All installations and
equipment using neon tubing, such as signs, decorative
elements, skeleton tubing, or art forms, are covered by this arti-
cle. Informational Note: Sign and outline lighting illumination
systems include, but are not limited to, cold cathode neon
tubing, high-intensity discharge lamps (HID), fluorescent or
incandescent lamps, light-emitting diodes (LEDs), and electro-
luminescent and inductance lighting. 600.3 Listing. Fixed, mobile, or portable electric signs, section
signs, outline lighting, photovoltaic (PV) powered signs, and
retrofit kits, regardless of voltage, shall be listed and labeled,
provided with installation instructions, and installed in
conformance with that listing, unless otherwise approved by
special permission. (A) Field-Installed Skeleton Tubing. Field-installed skeleton
tubing shall not be required to be listed where installed in
conformance with this Code. (B) Outline Lighting. Outline lighting shall not be required to
be listed as a system when it consists of listed luminaires wired
in accordance with Chapter 3. 600.4 Markings. (A) Signs and Outline Lighting Systems. Signs and outline
lighting systems shall b

question: What markings are required for signs and outline lighting systems that contain lampholders for incandescent lamps, according to 600.4(C)?
answer: Signs and outline lighting systems with lampholders for incandescent lamps shall be marked to indicate the maximum allowable lamp wattage per lampholder. The markings shall be permanently installed, in letters at least 6 mm (1/4 in.) high, and shall be located where visible during relamping.

question: For the 'Main Switchboard (AC Recombiner) / Field AC Combiner' configuration, what is the current rating range of the air circuit breakers (ACB) used in the switchboard?
answer: The switchboard utilizes 800VAC rated air circuit breakers ACB (800A – 1200A).

660-800VAC Balance of System Equipment
Most Comprehensive Offerings / Up to 70% Domestic Content
EPEC has developed a comprehensive set of solutions available for 660-800VAC AC collection requirements. Our
equipment is designed and mfg. in the United States and performs with all inverter brands and sizes (250 / 275
/ 350kW) presently being sold in the USA. We realize that one size does not fit all though. Thus, we have
crafted solutions for multiple power block / topology layouts. We illustrate this flexibility below. The following
examples are based on a power block size of (4.2MVA), however, block size can reduce as required to meet
exact solar plant requirements.
Main Switchboard / Inverters in Array / Local Disconnect
EPEC switchboard is located at the transformer (either cable or bus
connected to MVT). MCCB’s in the SWBD are cabled out to
Inverters mounted throughout the array. EPEC’s 800VAC NF
disconnect provides required NEC local disconnecting means. Up
to (12) 350kW inverters or up to (15) 275kW inverters are
connected for a total power block size of 4.2MVA. Domestic
content 55-60% for SWBD. If a skidded (MVT + SWBD) solution
domestic content 70%.

switchboard utilizes 800VAC rated air circuit breakers ACB (800A –
1200A). These (4) ACB’s are fed by field mounted AC combiners,

question: According to Article 400.5(A), what table provides ampacities for flexible cords and flexible cables with not more than three current-carrying conductors?
answer: Table 400.5(A) (2) provides the ampacities for flexible cords and flexible cables with not more than three current-carrying conductors.

temperature rating of the cord or cable shall be applied t

question: When must the ampacity of each conductor be reduced from the three-conductor rating for flexible cords and cables?
answer: Where the number of current-carrying conductors exceeds three, the ampacity of each conductor shall be reduced from the three-conductor rating as shown in Table 400.5 (A) (3).

question: According to NEC 2023, Section 200.6(A), what are the acceptable methods for identifying grounded conductors of size 6 AWG or smaller?
answer: The insulation of grounded conductors of 6 AWG or smaller shall be identified by one of the following means: (1) A continuous white outer finish. (2) A continuous gray outer finish. (3) Three continuous white or gray stripes along the conductor's entire length on other than green insulation. (4) Conductors with white or gray insulation and colored tracer threads in the braid identifying the source of manufacture. (5) A single-conductor, sunlight-resistant, outdoor-rated cable used as a solidly grounded conductor in photovoltaic power systems, as permitted by 690.31 (C) (1), shall be identified at the time of installation by markings at terminations in accordance with 200.6 (A) (1) through (A) (4). (6) The grounded conductor of a mineral-insulated, metal-sheathed cable (Type MI) shall be identified at the time of installation by a distinctive white or gray marking at its terminations The marking shall encircle the conductor insulation. (7) Fixture wire shall comply with the requirements for grounded conductor identification in accordance with 402.8. (8) For aerial cable, the identification shall comply with one of the methods in 200.6(A) (1) through (A) (5), or by means of a ridge located on the exterior of the cable so as to identify it.

question: According to NEC 2023, Section 200.6(B), how must an insulated grounded conductor of size 4 AWG or larger be identified at the time of installation?
answer: At the time of installation, an insulated grounded conductor 4 AWG or larger shall be identified by a distinctive white or gray marking at its terminations. This marking shall encircle the conductor insulation.

question: According to NEC guidelines, what is the maximum allowable solar back-feed for a 100A service panel, expressed in Amperes?
source_document: NEP Microinverter BDM-550, BDM-650 Whitepaper AA, EH
context:
NEP’s BDM-550 & BDM-650 White Paper
August, 2025
Microinverters
...to enable more power while avoiding
sub-panel upgrade thresholds
these models complement the BDM-800
ideal for modules over 400Wdc
The residential solar industry includes a myriad of hurdles that can cause setbacks both monetarily and in meeting
deadlines. One major hurdle being main panel upgrades, which largely affects the smaller service ratings such as the
100A service panels.
Why 100A Panels Often Need Upgrading
• Limited capacity: A 100A panel may not support the additional load from solar back-feed, especially if the home
already has high electrical demand.
• 120% Rule: NEC guidelines allow solar back-feed up to 120% of the panel rating. For a 100A panel, that’s only
20A of allowable back-feed.
Upgrading a service panel can cost thousands on top of an already costly PV system and can delay project completions
weeks, even months, in some cases. NEP has a solution that is cost effective and that helps to avoid these additional
expenses and delayed completion timelines.
Strategic Advantages of NEP’s BDM-550 & BDM-650 Microinverters
• Avoids panel upgrade: By optimizing the AC output current by precise divisibility into the maximum back-feed
capacity, these models help stay within the 120% rule for back-feed on 100A panels.
• Flexible system design: Dual input microinverters reduce the number of branch circuits needed, simplifying
layout and permitting.
• Cost-effective scaling: Especially with the BDM-550

question: What is one advantage of using the BDM-550 & BDM-650 microinverters in terms of system design?
answer: Dual input microinverters reduce the number of branch circuits needed, simplifying layout and permitting.

question: According to 29 CFR 1910.269, how is the voltage of a circuit not effectively grounded determined?
answer: The voltage of a circuit not effectively grounded is the voltage between any two conductors. If one circuit is directly connected to and supplied from another circuit of higher voltage (as in the case of an autotransformer), both are considered as of the higher voltage, unless the circuit of lower voltage is effectively grounded, in which case its voltage is not determined by the circuit of higher voltage.

question: When backing up an Acquisuite, what file extension will the backup file have?
answer: .bak
context:
7/14/25, 5:57 AM Edit Article - PHPKB Knowledge Base Software
Acquisuite Backup and Restore
Backing Up An Acquisuite
1. While logged into the Acquisuite, drop down the “System” item and then choose “Backup / Restore”.
2. Click the “Create Backup” button which will download a .bak file to your computer. If you rename the backup file, be sure not to include any spaces as this will
prevent the restore from working. Don’t worry about the checkboxes as those are used for the restore.
3. In PowerTrack, create a folder under the site labeled “Acquisuite Backups”, and then choose add file under that folder.
4. Once you’re in the add file box, choose select file. By default, PowerTrack won’t let you see files that end in “.bak”, so you’ll need to select “All Files (*.*)” from
the dropdown box for file types. Once you select the .bak file you downloaded, you can select OK to upload it to PowerTrack. That’s it, you’re done!
Restoring An Acquisuite From A Backup
1. While logged into the Acquisuite, drop down the “System” item and then choose “Backup / Restore”.
2. Check all check boxes except for “Include Diagnostic Log Files” and click “Apply”

question: When restoring an Acquisuite from a backup, which checkbox should NOT be checked?
answer: Include Diagnostic Log Files

question: What are the primary physical hazards associated with an arc flash event?
answer: The primary physical hazards include temperatures hotter than the surface of the sun, molten metal, pressure waves, shrapnel, and blinding light.
source_document: Arc Flash Safety Guide for Field Technicians and Engineers
context:
Arc Flash Safety Guide for Field Technicians and Engineers
(Medium & High Voltage Systems)
1. Introduction: Why Arc Flash Safety Matters
Arc flash is one of the most dangerous hazards in electrical work. It occurs when an
electrical current leaves its intended path and travels through the air between conductors
or from a conductor to ground. The results can be catastrophic: temperatures hotter than
the surface of the sun, molten metal, pressure waves, shrapnel, and blinding light.
Key risks include:
• Severe burns (often fatal within seconds)
• Blast pressure causing blunt trauma or ruptured eardrums
• Flying molten copper/aluminum shrapnel penetrating PPE
• Secondary fires and equipment damage
• Long-term health effects: PTSD, hearing/vision loss, chronic injury
Takeaway: No job is worth cutting corners. The best arc flash defense is awareness,
preparation, and prevention.
2. Arc Flash Awareness
Before approaching any medium- or high-voltage gear, new techs and engineers must
understand:
• Where Arc Flash Happens:
o Switchgear, switchboards, MCCs, panelboards, and transformers
o Energized busbars, circuit breakers, contactors, and disconnects
o Improperly racked breakers, corroded terminations, or failed insulation
• Common Causes:
o Dropped tools or loose hardware

question: Besides switchgear and transformers, what are three specific pieces of electrical equipment where arc flash is likely to occur?
answer: Arc flash is likely to occur at switchboards, MCCs (Motor Control Centers), and panelboards.

question: What NEMA enclosure type is used for the CPS 100/125kW inverters, and what does this rating indicate?

context:

100/125kW, 1500Vdc String Inverters for North America
CPS SCH100/125KTL-DO/US-600
The 100 & 125kW high power CPS three phase string inverters are designed for ground mount applications. The units are high
performance, advanced and reliable inverters designed specifically for the North American environment and grid. High efficiency
at 99.1% peak and 98.5% CEC, wide operating voltages, broad temperature ranges and a NEMA Type 4X enclosure enable this
inverter platform to operate at high performance across many applications. The CPS 100/125kW products ship with the Standard
or Centralized Wire-box, each fully integrated and separable with AC and DC disconnect switches. The Standard Wire-box inlcudes
touch safe fusing for up to 20 strings. The CPS Flex Gateway enables communication, controls and remote product upgrades.

question: What is the maximum continuous operating temperature for this cable in a wet location?
answer: The cables are capable of operating continuously at the conductor temperature not in excess of 90°C for normal operation in wet and dry locations.

CU 600/1000V XLPE Insulation PVC Jacket XHHW-2. CT Rated -
Sunlight Resistant - For Direct Burial - Silicone Free
Type TC-ER Power Cable 600 or 1000 Volt Three Conductor Copper, Cross Linked Polyethylene (XLPE) insulation XHHW-2
Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Jacket with 1 Copper Ground (Bare or Insulated). CT Rated - Sunlight Resistant - For Direct Burial -
Silicone Free.
Image not to scale. See Table 1 for dimensions.
CONSTRUCTION:
1. Conductor: Class B compressed stranded bare copper per ASTM B3 and ASTM B8
2. Insulation: Cross Linked Polyethylene (XLPE) Type XHHW-2
3. Grounding Conductor: Class B compressed stranded bare copper per ASTM B3 and ASTM B8. (When present, cable
conductor sizes 8 & 6 AWG have an insulated green ground)
4. Filler: Paper filler (cable size 8 & 6 uses Polypropylene filler)
5. Binder: Polyester flat thread binder tape for cable sizes larger than 2 AWG
6. Overall Jacket: Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Jacket
APPLICATIONS AND FEATURES:
Southwire’s 600 or 1000 Volt Type TC-ER power cables are suited for use in wet and dry areas, conduits, ducts, troughs, trays,
directburial, aerial supported bya messenger, and where superiorelectrical propertiesare desired. These cablesare capable
of operating continuously at the conductor temperature not in excess of 90°C for normal operation in wet and dry locations,

locations per NEC Article 5

Sunlight Resistant - For Direct Burial - Silicone Free
Type TC-ER Power Cable 600 or 1000 Volt Three Conductor Copper, Cross Linked Polyethylene (XLPE) insulation XHHW-2
Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Jacket with 1 Copper Ground (Bare or Insulated). CT Rated - Sunlight Resistant - For Direct Burial -
Silicone Free.
Image not to scale. See Table 1 for dimensions.
CONSTRUCTION:
1. Conductor: Class B compressed stranded bare copper per ASTM B3 and ASTM B8
2. Insulation: Cross Linked Polyethylene (XLPE) Type XHHW-2
3. Grounding Conductor: Class B compressed stranded bare copper per ASTM B3 and ASTM B8. (When present, cable
conductor sizes 8 & 6 AWG have an insulated green ground)
4. Filler: Paper filler (cable size 8 & 6 uses Polypropylene filler)
5. Binder: Polyester flat thread binder tape for cable sizes larger than 2 AWG
6. Overall Jacket: Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Jacket
APPLICATIONS AND FEATURES:
Southwire’s 600 or 1000 Volt Type TC-ER power cables are suited for use in wet and dry areas, conduits, ducts, troughs, trays,
directburial, aerial supported bya messenger, and where superiorelectrical propertiesare desired. These cablesare capable
of operating continuously at the conductor temperature not in excess of 90°C for normal operation in wet and dry locations,
130°C for emergency overload, and 250°C for short circuit conditions. For uses in Class I, II, and III, Division 2 hazardous
locations per NEC Article 5

question: According to the document, what conditions, either alone or as the principal factor, do NOT constitute grounds for a claim of Force Majeure?
answer: Financial cost or failure to secure adequate labor or any necessary materials or equipment.

1.14 “Force Majeure” means any act or event that directly delays or prevents a Party from

this Agreement if such act or event, despite the exercise of reasonable efforts, cannot be avoided by, and
is beyond the reasonable control of and without the fault or negligence of, the Party relying thereon as

an extended grid power failure. However, financial cost or failure to secure adequate labor or any
necessary materials or equipment alone or as the principal factor shall not constitute grounds for a claim

question: What is the definition of IEER according to this document, including the formula used for its calculation?
answer: IEER means the Insolation-adjusted Expected Energy Ratio, calculated using the DAS as follows: (x) actual kWh divided by expected kWh, divided by (y) actual insolation (as measured by irradiance sensor) divided by expected insolation.

question: What is the maximum voltage rating range supported by the EV-2H Aluminum Vertical Disconnect Switch?
context:
> Disconnect Switches > GROUP OPERATED SWITCHES
C A T A L O G F L Y E R
EV-2H
Aluminum Vertical
Disconnect Switch
550 kV - 800 kV
Robust Current Transfer & Hinge
Mechanism Promote Maximum Reliability
Southern States’ latest innovation, the EV-2H, supports reliability through its unique
design. This heavy duty, highly efficient vertical break disconnect switch utilizes
independent mechanical and electrical systems to produce the strongest possible
design with the easiest accessible maintenance. An over toggle mechanism in both
open and closed positions prevents the possibility for the blade to close in extreme
weather and increases down force for high fault performance. Metal encased coil
spring counterbalances reduce operating effort, are impervious to weather, and
prevent catastrophic failure that is possible with linear springs. Using an all stainless
steel bearing also ensures a long life in all operating conditions.
BENEFITS SPECIFICATIONS
• Mechanical operation is independent of the moving current joints, allowing efficient Maximum Voltage Rating
high current transmitting that promotes switch reliability and useful life. 550 kV – 800 kV
• Superior mechanical strength & corrosion resistance Continuous Current Rating
• Self-cleaning roller bearings & reverse loop current contacts 2000 A / 3000 A / 4000 A
• Hinge over-toggle prevents closing in adverse weather conditions and utilizes high
downward force on the blade to prevent it from popping open

question: According to section 200.2(A), what is the minimum voltage rating required for the insulation of a grounded conductor in solidly grounded neutral systems exceeding 1000 volts, as per 250.184(A)?
answer: The insulation must be rated not less than 600 volts.
context:
CHAPTER 2
 ARTICLE 200-USE AND IDENTIFICATION OF GROUNDED CONDUCTORS
 ARTICLE 200
 Chapter 2 Wiring and Protection
 Use and Identification of Grounded
 Conductors
 200.1 Scope. This article provides requirements for the follow-
ing:
 (1) Identification of terminals
 (2) Grounded conductors in premises wiring systems
(3) Identification of grounded conductors
 Informational Note: See Article 100 for definitions of Grounded
Conductor, Equipment Grounding Conductor, and Grounding Electrode
Conductor. 200.2 General. Grounded conductors shall comply with
200.2(A) and (B). (A) Insulation. The grounded conductor, if insulated, shall
have insulation that complies with either one of the following:
(1) Is suitably rated, other than color, for any ungrounded
conductor of the same circuit for systems of 1000 volts or
less. (2) Is rated not less than 600 volts for solidly grounded
neutral systems of over 1000 volts in accordance with
250.184(A)
 (B) Continuity. The continuity of a grounded conductor shall
not depend on a connection to a metal enclosure, raceway, or
cable armor. Informational Note: See 300.13(B) for the continuity of groun-
ded conductors used in multiwire branch circuits. 200.3 Connection to Grounded System. Grounded conductors
of premises wiring systems shall be electrically connected to the
supply system grounded conductor to ensure a common,
continuous grounded system. For the purpose of this section,
electrically connected shall mean making a direct electrical
connecti

question: As stated in 200.4(B), how should grounded circuit conductors associated with different circuits be identified or grouped within an enclosure containing more than one neutral conductor?
answer: Grounded circuit conductors of each circuit shall be identified or grouped to correspond with the ungrounded circuit conductor(s) by wire markers, cable ties, or similar means in at least one location within the enclosure.

question: What is the maximum continuous operating temperature of the conductor for this cable in normal operation, both in wet and dry locations?
answer: The cables are capable of operating continuously at the conductor temperature not in excess of 90°C for normal operation in wet and dry locations.

CU 600/1000V XLPE Insulation PVC Jacket XHHW-2. CT Rated -
Sunlight Resistant - For Direct Burial - Silicone Free
Type TC-ER Power Cable 600 or 1000 Volt Three Conductor Copper, Cross Linked Polyethylene (XLPE) insulation XHHW-2
Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Jacket with 1 Copper Ground (Bare or Insulated). CT Rated - Sunlight Resistant - For Direct Burial -
Silicone Free.
Image not to scale. See Table 1 for dimensions.
CONSTRUCTION:
1. Conductor: Class B compressed stranded bare copper per ASTM B3 and ASTM B8
2. Insulation: Cross Linked Polyethylene (XLPE) Type XHHW-2
3. Grounding Conductor: Class B compressed stranded bare copper per ASTM B3 and ASTM B8. (When present, cable
conductor sizes 8 & 6 AWG have an insulated green ground)
4. Filler: Paper filler (cable size 8 & 6 uses Polypropylene filler)
5. Binder: Polyester flat thread binder tape for cable sizes larger than 2 AWG
6. Overall Jacket: Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Jacket
APPLICATIONS AND FEATURES:
Southwire’s 600 or 1000 Volt Type TC-ER power cables are suited for use in wet and dry areas, conduits, ducts, troughs, trays,
directburial, aerial supported bya messenger, and where superiorelectrical propertiesare desired. These cablesare capable
of operating continuously at the conductor temperature not in excess of 90°C for normal operation in wet and dry locations,
130°C for emergency overload, and 250°C for short circuit conditions. For uses in Class I, II, and III, Division 2 hazardous
locations per NEC Article 5

CHAPTER 6

 Chapter 6 Special Equipment
 ARTICLE 600
 Electric Signs and Outline Lighting
 Part I. General
 600.1 Scope. This article covers the installation of conductors,
equipment, and field wiring for electric signs, retrofit kits, and
outline lighting, regardless of voltage. All installations and
equipment using neon tubing, such as signs, decorative
elements, skeleton tubing, or art forms, are covered by this arti-
cle. Informational Note: Sign and outline lighting illumination
systems include, but are not limited to, cold cathode neon
tubing, high-intensity discharge lamps (HID), fluorescent or
incandescent lamps, light-emitting diodes (LEDs), and electro-
luminescent and inductance lighting. 600.3 Listing. Fixed, mobile, or portable electric signs, section
signs, outline lighting, photovoltaic (PV) powered signs, and
retrofit kits, regardless of voltage, shall be listed and labeled,
provided with installation instructions, and installed in
conformance with that listing, unless otherwise approved by
special permission. (A) Field-Installed Skeleton Tubing. Field-installed skeleton
tubing shall not be required to be listed where installed in
conformance with this Code. (B) Outline Lighting. Outline lighting shall not be required to
be listed as a system when it consists of listed luminaires wired

lighting systems shall b

question: As per NEC 2023 Article 600.4(C), what are the requirements for marking signs and outline lighting systems with lampholders for incandescent lamps, in terms of content, size, and location?
answer: The signs and outline lighting systems shall be marked to indicate the maximum allowable lamp wattage per lampholder. The markings shall be permanently installed, in letters at least 6 mm (1/4 in.) high, and shall be located where visible during relamping.

question: For the "Main Switchboard (AC Recombiner) / Field AC Combiner" configuration, what amperage range are the 800VAC rated air circuit breakers (ACB) in the switchboard?
answer: The switchboard utilizes 800VAC rated air circuit breakers ACB (800A – 1200A).
context:
660-800VAC Balance of System Equipment
Most Comprehensive Offerings / Up to 70% Domestic Content
EPEC has developed a comprehensive set of solutions available for 660-800VAC AC collection requirements. Our
equipment is designed and mfg. in the United States and performs with all inverter brands and sizes (250 / 275
/ 350kW) presently being sold in the USA. We realize that one size does not fit all though. Thus, we have
crafted solutions for multiple power block / topology layouts. We illustrate this flexibility below. The following
examples are based on a power block size of (4.2MVA), however, block size can reduce as required to meet
exact solar plant requirements.
Main Switchboard / Inverters in Array / Local Disconnect
EPEC switchboard is located at the transformer (either cable or bus
connected to MVT). MCCB’s in the SWBD are cabled out to
Inverters mounted throughout the array. EPEC’s 800VAC NF
disconnect provides required NEC local disconnecting means. Up
to (12) 350kW inverters or up to (15) 275kW inverters are
connected for a total power block size of 4.2MVA. Domestic
content 55-60% for SWBD. If a skidded (MVT + SWBD) solution
domestic content 70%.
Main Switchboard (AC Recombiner) / Field AC Combiner
EPEC modular (multi-section) switchboard is located at the
transformer (either cable or bus connected to MVT). The
switchboard utilizes 800VAC rated air circuit breakers ACB (800A –
1200A). These (4) ACB’s are fed by field mounted AC combiners,
each of which can combine u

question: What specific safety rule was violated during inverter troubleshooting, and what action was taken to correct it?
answer: A technician reached into the inverter cabinet without voltage testing the bus first, violating the "test-before-touch" rule. The technician was stopped and reminded of the rule, after which work resumed safely.
context:
10. While conducting a lockout/tagout, I noticed the tag did not include the technician’s
full name and date. Incomplete information could cause confusion during shift
handover. The tag was corrected immediately.
11. On the way to a solar site, our truck’s low tire pressure indicator came on. We pulled
over and confirmed one tire was at 50% pressure. It was unsafe to continue until the
tire was repaired.
12. While walking a PV array row, I tripped slightly over a grounding cable that was not
secured tightly. This could easily cause a fall. I reported it and placed a cone until
repair.
13. During inverter troubleshooting, a technician reached into the cabinet without
voltage testing the bus first. I stopped them and reminded them of the test-before-
touch rule. Work resumed safely afterward.
14. At the EV charging site, I saw an extension cord being used across a walkway. It
posed a trip hazard for pedestrians. I re-routed the cord overhead with a hook.
15. While performing a harness check, I noticed one lanyard hook was cracked. Using
this could have resulted in fall arrest failure. The equipment was tagged out and
replaced.
16. Driving through a rural access road, I saw deer crossing ahead. Quick braking
prevented a collision, but it reinforced the need to watch wildlife in these areas. The
crew was reminded at tailboard.
17. At a BESS container, a technician attempted to bypass a panel interlock. I stopped
the work and reinforced that interlocks must never be bypassed. The

question: What is the default IP address assigned to the AcquiSuite when it is configured to use a cellular modem?
answer: The default IP Address is 192.168.2.50.
context:
2/25/2019 https://sites.google.com/a/locusenergy.com/wiki/cls-support/c-i-training/acquisuite-basics---external?tmpl=%2Fsystem%2Fapp%2Ftempl…
Support > C &I Training >
AcquiSuite Basics - External
AcquiSuite Basics - External
Intended for internal support reference.
AcquiSuite EMB A8810
WHAT IS IT:
The AcquiSuite is the datalogger that we use on most of our commercial sites. It is able
to detect and collect data from a variety of external devices. This document will outline
common checks we can perform externally (without logging into the AcquiSuite with a
laptop) in order to troubleshoot more efficiently.
SETTINGS CHECK:
The AcquiSuite often uses one of our cellular modems (the Digi or Multitech) to
connect but can also use a local area network. For local area network connections,
we can set the AcquiSuite to DHCP mode but if there are specific network
requirements, they will need to obtain those from the IT department for that
network.
Common Network Settings for AcquiSuite using our cell modem:
DHCP+UPnP = disabled
IP Address = 192.168.2.50
Netmask = 255.255.255.0

question: When the AcquiSuite uses a cellular modem for network connectivity, what is the recommended setting for DHCP+UPnP?
answer: DHCP+UPnP should be disabled.

question: According to the document, what events are explicitly excluded from constituting grounds for a claim of Force Majeure?
answer: Financial cost or failure to secure adequate labor or any necessary materials or equipment alone or as the principal factor.
context:
Template
1.14 “Force Majeure” means any act or event that directly delays or prevents a Party from
timely performing obligations under this Agreement or from complying with conditions required under
this Agreement if such act or event, despite the exercise of reasonable efforts, cannot be avoided by, and
is beyond the reasonable control of and without the fault or negligence of, the Party relying thereon as
justification for such delay, nonperformance, or noncompliance, which includes, without limitation, an
act of God or the elements, extreme or severe weather conditions, explosion, fire, epidemic, landslide,
mudslide, sabotage, terrorism, lightning, earthquake, flood, volcanic eruption or similar cataclysmic event,
an act of the public enemy, war, blockade, civil insurrection, riot, civil disturbance, or strike or other labor
difficulty caused or suffered by a Party or any third party beyond the reasonable control of such Party, or
an extended grid power failure. However, financial cost or failure to secure adequate labor or any
necessary materials or equipment alone or as the principal factor shall not constitute grounds for a claim
of Force Majeure. 1.15 “Governmental Authorities” shall mean each of the United States of America, the State
of Connecticut, and local municipal governments, in each case to the extent having jurisdiction over

question: How is the Insolation-adjusted Expected Energy Ratio (IEER) calculated, according to the document?
answer: IEER is calculated using the DAS as follows: (x) actual kWh divided by expected kWh, divided by (y) actual insolation (as measured by irradiance sensor) divided by expected insolation.

question: What are some of the key physical hazards associated with an arc flash event?
answer: Key risks include severe burns, blast pressure causing blunt trauma or ruptured eardrums, flying molten copper/aluminum shrapnel penetrating PPE, and secondary fires and equipment damage.
source_document: Arc Flash Safety Guide for Field Technicians and Engineers
context:
Arc Flash Safety Guide for Field Technicians and Engineers
(Medium & High Voltage Systems)
1. Introduction: Why Arc Flash Safety Matters
Arc flash is one of the most dangerous hazards in electrical work. It occurs when an
electrical current leaves its intended path and travels through the air between conductors
or from a conductor to ground. The results can be catastrophic: temperatures hotter than
the surface of the sun, molten metal, pressure waves, shrapnel, and blinding light.
Key risks include:
• Severe burns (often fatal within seconds)
• Blast pressure causing blunt trauma or ruptured eardrums
• Flying molten copper/aluminum shrapnel penetrating PPE
• Secondary fires and equipment damage
• Long-term health effects: PTSD, hearing/vision loss, chronic injury
Takeaway: No job is worth cutting corners. The best arc flash defense is awareness,
preparation, and prevention.
2. Arc Flash Awareness
Before approaching any medium- or high-voltage gear, new techs and engineers must
understand:
• Where Arc Flash Happens:
o Switchgear, switchboards, MCCs, panelboards, and transformers
o Energized busbars, circuit breakers, contactors, and disconnects
o Improperly racked breakers, corroded terminations, or failed insulation
• Common Causes:
o Dropped tools or loose hardware

question: Besides switchgear and transformers, what other specific pieces of electrical equipment are listed as locations where arc flash events can occur?
answer: Arc flash events can occur in switchboards, MCCs, panelboards, energized busbars, circuit breakers, contactors, and disconnects.

question: According to NEC 2023 Article 200.2(A), what voltage rating is required for the insulation of a grounded conductor in a solidly grounded neutral system operating at over 1000 volts?
answer: The insulation must be rated not less than 600 volts for solidly grounded neutral systems of over 1000 volts in accordance with 250.184(A).

question: Under what condition is a listed interactive inverter permitted to be connected to premises wiring without a grounded conductor, according to Article 200.3?
answer: A listed interactive inverter identified for use in distributed resource generation systems such as photovoltaic and fuel cell power systems shall be permitted to be connected to premises wiring without a grounded conductor if the connected premises wiring or utility system includes a grounded conductor.

question: What are three common causes of arc flash incidents related to electrical equipment maintenance or procedures?
answer: Incorrect racking or removal of breakers, failure to verify absence of voltage, and defeated or bypassed interlocks.
source_document: Arc Flash Safety Guide for Field Technicians and Engineers
context:
o Incorrect racking or removal of breakers
o Failure to verify absence of voltage
o Defeated or bypassed interlocks
o Inadequate maintenance leading to degraded insulation or loose
connections
• Warning Signs:
o Equipment humming, buzzing, or smelling like ozone/burning insulation
o Visible damage (pitting, discoloration, cracks)
o Heat at terminals or unexpected hot spots (use IR thermography when safe)
Golden Rule: Treat all gear as energized until proven otherwise with proper testing.
3. Preparedness: Planning Before the Job
Preparation is 90% of arc flash prevention.
3.1 Documentation & Work Planning
• Review one-line diagrams and protective device coordination studies.
• Consult the Arc Flash Hazard Analysis/Labeling for each piece of gear.
• Understand the incident energy levels and PPE category.
• Prepare switching orders and lockout/tagout (LOTO) sequences.
3.2 Job Briefings
• Hold a tailboard / job hazard analysis (JHA) before beginning work.
• Confirm roles: who is qualified, who observes, who communicates with system
operations.
• Identify energized work boundaries (limited, restricted, prohibited).
• Establish an escape path in case of failure.
3.3 Tools & Test Equipment
• Voltage detectors (rated for system voltage)
• Properly rated insulated tools

question: Considering the potential arc flash hazards in switchboards as outlined in the safety guide, what specific components within the EPEC 1200-6000A UL 891 switchboard, such as breakers or busbars, could be potential sources of arc flash incidents, and what are the potential consequences?
answer: Based on the Arc Flash Safety Guide, potential arc flash locations within the EPEC switchboard include energized busbars, circuit breakers (specifically Siemens 3WA and 3VA6), and improperly racked breakers or corroded terminations. The consequences could include severe burns, blast pressure causing trauma, molten metal shrapnel, secondary fires, and long-term health effects like PTSD and vision/hearing loss.
reasoning: This question requires information from both documents. The Arc Flash Safety Guide provides the general hazards and consequences of arc flash. The EPEC switchboard document specifies the components present in the switchboard (breakers, busbars) and their ratings, allowing for a more specific assessment of potential arc flash sources.

contexts:
Arc Flash Safety Guide for Field Technicians and Engineers
(Medium & High Voltage Systems)
1. Introduction: Why Arc Flash Safety Matters
Arc flash is one of the most dangerous hazards in electrical work. It occurs when an
electrical current leaves its intended path and travels through the air between conductors
or from a conductor to ground. The results can be catastrophic: temperatures hotter than
the surface of the sun, molten metal, pressure waves, shrapnel, and blinding light.
Key risks include:
• Severe burns (often fatal within seconds)
• Blast pressure causing blunt trauma or ruptured eardrums
• Flying molten copper/aluminum shrapnel penetrating PPE
• Secondary fires and equipment damage
• Long-term health effects: PTSD, hearing/vision loss, chronic injury
Takeaway: No job is worth cutting corners. The best arc flash defense is awareness,
preparation, and prevention.

question: If I am using a CPS SCH125KTL-DO/US-600 inverter connected to PowerTrack and need to restore its configuration from a backup, where do I store the '.bak' file created from the Acquisuite backup, and what specific file type must be selected in PowerTrack to upload it?
answer: The '.bak' file should be stored in a folder labeled 'Acquisuite Backups' under the site in PowerTrack. To upload it, you need to select 'All Files (*.*)' from the dropdown box for file types in PowerTrack because PowerTrack does not display '.bak' files by default.
reasoning: This question requires knowing that Acquisuite backups are stored in PowerTrack (Document 1) and that the CPS inverter is connected to PowerTrack (Document 2, inferring remote monitoring/management capabilities through the CPS Flex Gateway). It also requires understanding the specific steps for uploading a '.bak' file in PowerTrack (Document 1).
contexts:
7/14/25, 5:57 AM Edit Article - PHPKB Knowledge Base Software
Acquisuite Backup and Restore
Backing Up An Acquisuite
1. While logged into the Acquisuite, drop down the “System” item and then choose “Backup / Restore”.
2. Click the “Create Backup” button which will download a .bak file to your computer. If you rename the backup file, be sure not to include any spaces as this will
prevent the restore from working. Don’t worry about the checkboxes as those are used for the restore.
3. In PowerTrack, create a folder under the site labeled “Acquisuite Backups”, and then choose add file under that folder.
4. Once you’re in the add file box, choose select file. By default, PowerTrack won’t let you see files that end in “.bak”, so you’ll need to select “All Files (*.*)” from
the dropdown box for file types. Once you select the .bak file you downloaded, you can select OK to upload it to PowerTrack. That’s it, you’re done!

question: Considering a 480VAC, 3P3W, 6000A single-ended EPEC UL 891 certified SWBD with a main breaker, what considerations, as per NEC Article 200, should be made regarding the insulation and continuity of the grounded conductor within the premises wiring system connected to this SWBD?
answer: According to NEC Article 200, the grounded conductor, if insulated, must be suitably rated for any ungrounded conductor of the same circuit because the system voltage is 1000 volts or less. Additionally, the continuity of the grounded conductor should not depend on a connection to a metal enclosure, raceway, or cable armor. The SWBD is a 480VAC system, which falls under the <1000V requirement.

Arc Flash Safety Guide for Field Technicians and Engineers
(Medium & High Voltage Systems)
1. Introduction: Why Arc Flash Safety Matters
Arc flash is one of the most dangerous hazards in electrical work. It occurs when an
electrical current leaves its intended path and travels through the air between conductors
or from a conductor to ground. The results can be catastrophic: temperatures hotter than
the surface of the sun, molten metal, pressure waves, shrapnel, and blinding light.
Key risks include:
• Severe burns (often fatal within seconds)
• Blast pressure causing blunt trauma or ruptured eardrums
• Flying molten copper/aluminum shrapnel penetrating PPE
• Secondary fires and equipment damage
• Long-term health effects: PTSD, hearing/vision loss, chronic injury
Takeaway: No job is worth cutting corners. The best arc flash defense is awareness,
preparation, and prevention.

question: According to NEC 200.3, what is the general requirement for grounded conductors in premises wiring systems, and how does this requirement relate to the use of interactive inverters, such as those used in solar power systems, when connected to premises wiring without a grounded conductor?
answer: Grounded conductors of premises wiring systems must be electrically connected to the supply system grounded conductor to ensure a common, continuous grounded system. However, NEC 200.3 provides an exception for listed interactive inverters in distributed resource generation systems like photovoltaic systems. These inverters can be connected to premises wiring without a grounded conductor if the connected premises wiring or utility system includes a grounded conductor.
reasoning: This question requires understanding the general grounding requirements from the NEC document and then understanding the exception related to solar power systems (interactive inverters) which is also found in the NEC document. The DiGi document confirms solar power systems are relevant.

question: For a 480VAC, 4000A switchboard installed below ground in a vault, what considerations must be made regarding ventilation according to OSHA standards, and what interrupt rating should be expected from the switchboard?
answer: According to OSHA, an underground vault must be either vented or unvented. A vented vault has provisions for air changes using exhaust flue stacks and low-level air intakes. The BDM-1200-LV's built-in WiFi, as described in its datasheet, allows for real-time performance monitoring, troubleshooting, and alerts via a smartphone app. This would enable remote diagnosis of the failure, potentially confirming the grid power issue as the root cause and aiding in the Force Majeure claim.

question: If a solar power project using a Shark 100 electricity meter is experiencing performance issues due to a severe weather condition considered a Force Majeure event according to the EPC contract, what specific meter readings should be analyzed to determine the Insolation-adjusted Expected Energy Ratio (IEER) to assess the impact of the weather on energy production?
answer: The Shark 100 meter readings needed are actual kWh, which are used in the IEER calculation: (x) actual kWh divided by expected kWh, divided by (y) actual insolation (as measured by irradiance sensor) divided by expected insolation. The EPC contract defines Force Majeure as including severe weather conditions that prevent timely performance. Therefore, both documents are needed to link the performance issue (potentially caused by a Force Majeure event) to the specific meter readings required for IEER calculation.

question: According to the National Electrical Code and based on EPEC Solutions' product line, what considerations should be made for grounded conductor insulation in a 1200-6000A UL 891 switchboard designed for critical power applications?
answer: According to NEC Article 200.2(A), the grounded conductor insulation should either be suitably rated for any ungrounded conductor of the same circuit for systems of 1000 volts or less, or be rated not less than 600 volts for solidly grounded neutral systems of over 1000 volts. When applying this to an EPEC Solutions 1200-6000A UL 891 switchboard for critical power, the voltage rating of the switchboard needs to be considered to select the appropriate insulation rating for the grounded conductors.

question: If a manufacturing plant with a 480VAC, 1000A electrical service panel is considering installing a solar array with microinverters, what is the maximum allowable solar back-feed current according to NEC guidelines, and would using NEP BDM-550 or BDM-650 microinverters be a viable solution to avoid upgrading the existing service panel assuming the plant needs to add 30A of backfeed?
answer: The maximum allowable solar back-feed for a 1000A panel is 1200A (120% of 1000A). The plant will need to upgrade the electrical service if they add 30A of backfeed to an existing 1000A panel because they will exceed the maximum allowable solar back-feed of 1200A. The NEP microinverters may be a viable solution to avoid upgrading the service panel if the back-feed can be optimized to stay within the 120% rule.
reasoning: This question requires understanding the voltage and current ratings of switchboards from Document 1 and applying the 120% rule for solar back-feed mentioned in Document 2 to determine if a panel upgrade is necessary. It also tests understanding of how NEP microinverters can help avoid panel upgrades.

The residential solar industry includes a myriad of hurdles that can cause setbacks both monetarily and in meeting
deadlines. One major hurdle being main panel upgrades, which largely affects the smaller service ratings such as the
100A service panels.
Why 100A Panels Often Need Upgrading
• Limited capacity: A 100A panel may not support the additional load from solar back-feed, especially if the home
already has high electrical demand.
• 120% Rule: NEC guidelines allow solar back-feed up to 120% of the panel rating. For a 100A panel, that’s only
20A of allowable back-feed.
Upgrading a service panel can cost thousands on top of an already costly PV system and can delay project completions

question: After backing up the Acquisuite data from Boyne Mountain Resort, where should the .bak file be stored, and what special consideration must be taken when uploading it to ensure it is visible for selection?
answer: The .bak file should be stored in a folder labeled "Acquisuite Backups" under the site in PowerTrack. When uploading, you need to select "All Files (*.*)" from the dropdown box for file types in PowerTrack to make the .bak file visible.
reasoning: Document 1 provides instructions on backing up and restoring Acquisuite, including the specific steps for storing the .bak file in PowerTrack and the file type selection. Document 2 identifies "BOYNE MOUNTAIN RESORT" as the site associated with the Acquisuite in question. Both are required to understand the full context of the question and provide a complete answer.

Acquisuite Backup and Restore
Backing Up An Acquisuite
1. While logged into the Acquisuite, drop down the “System” item and then choose “Backup / Restore”.
2. Click the “Create Backup” button which will download a .bak file to your computer. If you rename the backup file, be sure not to include any spaces as this will
prevent the restore from working. Don’t worry about the checkboxes as those are used for the restore.
3. In PowerTrack, create a folder under the site labeled “Acquisuite Backups”, and then choose add file under that folder.
4. Once you’re in the add file box, choose select file. By default, PowerTrack won’t let you see files that end in “.bak”, so you’ll need to select “All Files (*.*)” from
the dropdown box for file types. Once you select the .bak file you downloaded, you can select OK to upload it to PowerTrack. That’s it, you’re done!
Restoring An Acquisuite From A Backup

question: Considering the types of group operated disconnect switches listed in the Southern States Group Operated Switch Application Guide, and the power monitoring capabilities of the Shark 100/100T electricity meter described in its user manual, how could the Shark 100/100T be used to monitor the performance and detect potential failures in a double end break group operated switch installation?
answer: The Shark 100/100T could be used to monitor voltage and current on either side of the double end break switch. By comparing the readings, one can confirm the switch is effectively isolating the circuit when open, or properly conducting when closed. Deviations from expected values, such as voltage leakage when open or significant current imbalance when closed, could indicate switch degradation or failure.
reasoning: The question requires identifying the types of switches from the Southern States document and then relating that to the monitoring capabilities of the Shark meter from the other document, specifically how the meter data could inform the operation of that specific type of switch.

question: If a vertical break group operated switch, as detailed in the Southern States guide, is installed in a system also being monitored by a Shark 100 electricity meter, what specific electrical parameters reported by the Shark 100 would be most critical to observe in order to confirm the switch is functioning correctly during both opening and closing operations?
answer: The most critical parameters would be voltage, current, and power factor. During opening, a sudden drop in current to near zero and consistent voltage readings on both sides of the open switch would indicate proper isolation. During closing, a smooth and balanced increase in current and a power factor close to the expected system value would confirm proper connection and load sharing.
reasoning: This question requires knowing that a vertical break switch exists (from the Southern States doc) and then understanding which electrical parameters the Shark 100 meter measures (from the other doc) and how these parameters relate to the correct functionality of this specific type of switch.

question: In the context of a Green-Earth-Energy EPC contract, if an extended grid power failure causes a delay in project completion, and flexible cables used in the solar installation are rated for 90°C ambient temperature, how would the ampacity of these cables be adjusted according to the National Electrical Code to account for temperatures exceeding 30°C (86°F), considering the Force Majeure clause?
answer: The EPC contract defines an extended grid power failure as a potential 'Force Majeure' event, which may excuse delays in project completion. According to the National Electrical Code, specifically Article 400.5(A), if flexible cables rated for 90°C are used in ambient temperatures exceeding 30°C (86°F), the temperature correction factors from Table 310.15(B)(1)(1) corresponding to the 90°C column must be applied to the ampacity in Table 400.5(A)(1) and Table 400.5(A)(2). This adjustment ensures the cables are operated within their safe operating limits, even during a Force Majeure event like a grid power failure that might affect ambient temperatures or cable loading.
reasoning: This question requires information from both documents. The EPC contract defines 'Force Majeure' and includes 'an extended grid power failure.' The National Electrical Code provides specifics on how to adjust the ampacity of flexible cables based on ambient temperature, referencing specific tables within the code. Answering the question necessitates understanding the contract's definition of Force Majeure and applying the NEC's temperature correction rules for flexible cables.

question: According to the NEC, what markings are required on a listed electric sign with a retrofitted illumination system, and what type of cable, as specified by Southwire, is suitable for direct burial to power this sign in a wet location?
answer: According to NEC Article 600.4(B), signs with a retrofitted illumination system must be marked to indicate the system has been replaced and include the kit provider's and installer's name, logo, or unique identifier. Southwire's SPEC 45051 CU 600V PVC-Nylon Insulation PVC Jacket THHN/THWN-2 Type TC-ER control cable is suitable for direct burial in wet locations, operating continuously at a conductor temperature not exceeding 75°C.
reasoning: This question requires information from both documents. The first part of the question about markings comes from the NEC article regarding electric signs. The second part of the question regarding suitable cable for direct burial comes from the Southwire SPEC 45051 document. It requires synthesizing information from both sources to provide a complete answer.

question: Can Southern States' quick break arcing horns, used to interrupt line charging current on high voltage switches, be integrated as an accessory within an EPEC Solutions UL 891 certified SWBD operating at 480VAC, and if so, what considerations regarding interrupt ratings would need to be addressed?
answer: Southern States' quick break arcing horns are designed for high voltage switches, as described in Bulletin 1400-A, while the EPEC Solutions SWBD operates at 480VAC or 600VAC according to the flyer. Integrating a high-voltage accessory within a low-voltage SWBD would not be a standard application and would likely require significant engineering modifications and careful consideration of interrupt ratings (100kAIC @ 480VAC and 65kAIC @ 600VAC for the SWBD) to ensure safe and effective operation.
reasoning: This question requires understanding the voltage levels at which the Southern States arcing horns and the EPEC Solutions SWBD operate, information found in both documents. It also requires synthesizing that information to determine the feasibility and potential challenges of integrating these components.

Arc Flash Safety Guide for Field Technicians and Engineers
(Medium & High Voltage Systems)
1. Introduction: Why Arc Flash Safety Matters
Arc flash is one of the most dangerous hazards in electrical work. It occurs when an
electrical current leaves its intended path and travels through the air between conductors
or from a conductor to ground. The results can be catastrophic: temperatures hotter than
the surface of the sun, molten metal, pressure waves, shrapnel, and blinding light.
Key risks include:
• Severe burns (often fatal within seconds)
• Blast pressure causing blunt trauma or ruptured eardrums
• Flying molten copper/aluminum shrapnel penetrating PPE
• Secondary fires and equipment damage
• Long-term health effects: PTSD, hearing/vision loss, chronic injury
Takeaway: No job is worth cutting corners. The best arc flash defense is awareness,
preparation, and prevention.
